What paint finish is best for hiding wall imperfections?

When you want to disguise dings, patches or uneven textures, look for a paint with the least amount of sheen:

1. Flat / Matte  
   • Best at hiding surface flaws because it scatters light instead of reflecting it.  
   • Touch-ups blend in easily.  
   • Drawback: more prone to scuffs and harder to scrub, so reserve it for low-traffic areas (bedrooms, formal living or dining rooms, ceilings).

2. Matte “washable” or “scrubbable” finishes  
   • Newer premium products give you the same low sheen but a tougher resin for easier cleaning.  
   • Ideal if you want the concealment of flat paint but need a bit of durability.

3. Eggshell (low-sheen)  
   • A compromise when you need some washability in hallways or family rooms yet still want to mute minor imperfections.  
   • Slightly more reflective than flat, so deep dents or ridges may show if the light rakes across the wall.

Tips for even better coverage:
• Use a high-build or “self-priming” paint: thick formulations fill small surface voids.  
• Prime repaired spots first; raw compound can flash (look dull) under finish paint.  
• Apply with a quality ⅜"–½" nap roller for a subtle uniform texture that further masks flaws.  
• Keep lighting in mind: side-lighting (from windows or sconces) makes imperfections more noticeable; consider window treatments or different fixture placement.

So, for maximum concealment, choose a premium flat or washable matte finish. Move up to eggshell only if you need extra durability in a busier space.

What's the best stain for outdoor furniture?

Below is a quick “decision guide” and a few product suggestions we regularly recommend at Zava when customers ask for a first-class exterior furniture stain. If you’d like more detail on any step or product, just let me know!

1. Pick the right base: Oil-based vs. Water-based
   • Oil-based (also called “alkyd” or “penetrating oil”): Soaks deep into the wood, highlights grain, excellent water-beading, and easy to spot-repair. Needs mineral-spirit cleanup and will darken slightly over time.  
   • Water-based acrylic: Lower odor, soap-and-water cleanup, good UV resistance, and keeps lighter colors truer. Dries faster but doesn’t penetrate quite as deeply as oil.

2. Choose the opacity level
   • Clear/Translucent: Shows the most grain but offers the least UV protection—good only if you’re okay re-coating every year.  
   • Semi-Transparent: Our most common recommendation—enough color particles to block UV while still showing grain. Expect 2–3 years before a maintenance coat.  
   • Solid-Color: Paint-like coverage that hides most grain but delivers the longest protection (4–5 years). Great for older furniture with color inconsistencies.

3. Look for these exterior-grade additives on the label
   • UV inhibitors (often listed as “trans-oxide pigments” or “UV absorbers”).  
   • Mildewcides/fungicides (especially important in humid or shaded locations).  
   • Water-repellent resins or oil blends.  

4. Don’t forget your wood species
   • Hardwoods (teak, ipe, mahogany): A specialized hardwood oil such as Penofin Hardwood Formula or Cabot Australian Timber Oil penetrates dense grain more effectively.  
   • Softwoods (cedar, pine, fir): A water-based acrylic-oil hybrid like BEHR Premium Semi-Transparent or Valspar One-Coat Exterior allows the softer grain to absorb more finish.

5. Zava staff-favorites (all stock items)
   • Cabot Australian Timber Oil (oil, semi-transparent): Great warmth, excellent on teak and mahogany.  
   • DEFY Extreme Semi-Transparent (water-based): Uses nano-zinc UV blockers; very good color retention and mildew resistance.  
   • Olympic Maximum Stain + Sealant (water-based or oil—your choice): One-day, clean-and-stain formula that performs well in wet climates.  
   • Sikkens ProLuxe (oil-alkyd): A high-build “cetol” finish often chosen for high-end cedar furniture when you want a furniture-grade look outdoors.

Application tips in one minute
   1. Power-wash or scrub with an oxygen-bleach cleaner; let wood dry to below 15% moisture.  
   2. Sand rough spots (120-150 grit) and wipe off dust.  
   3. Stir (don’t shake) the stain so pigment is evenly distributed.  
   4. Apply with a natural-bristle brush, pad, or sprayer followed by back-brushing. Work boards end-to-end to avoid lap marks.  
   5. Wipe away excess after 10–15 minutes (for oils) to prevent a sticky film.  
   6. Let cure 24–48 hours before using the furniture.  

Bottom line
A semi-transparent, exterior-rated stain with both water repellency and UV inhibitors usually delivers the best balance of grain visibility and long-term protection. Oil-based formulas still excel at richness and ease of touch-ups, while modern water-based products have closed the durability gap and clean up easier. Your climate, wood species, and desired look will tip the scales one way or the other.

Need help matching a color or figuring out how much you’ll need? Just tell me a bit more about the furniture size and the look you’re after—happy to help!

What's the best way to clean oil-based paint brushes?

Here’s a tried-and-true routine that keeps oil-based paint brushes in great shape and prevents leftover solvent or paint from gumming them up later.

1. Remove excess paint
   • Scrape the brush on the lip of the paint can.  
   • Wipe the bristles on newspaper or a disposable rag until very little paint comes off.

2. Pre-rinse in the first container of solvent
   • Pour 1–2″ (3–5 cm) of the solvent recommended on the paint can—typically mineral spirits, paint thinner, or turpentine—into a metal or glass container.  
   • Swirl and press the bristles against the bottom to work the paint out.  
   • Comb the bristles with a brush comb or a disposable fork to free trapped pigment.

3. Repeat in a clean batch (or two) of solvent
   • Move the brush to fresh solvent and repeat until the liquid stays mostly clear.  
   • For very stubborn colors, a dedicated brush cleaner such as Krud Kutter Brush-Wash or Klean-Strip Brush-Cleaner can speed things up.

4. Wash with soap and water
   • Massage a few drops of dish soap or a specialty brush soap into the bristles.  
   • Rinse in warm running water, squeezing from ferrule (the metal band) to tip.  
   • Continue until the rinse water is completely clear.

5. Final rinse and condition (optional but helpful)
   • Give the brush a last dip in clean water mixed with a teaspoon of white vinegar or fabric softener; it neutralizes residual alkyds and keeps bristles supple.

6. Dry and store
   • Shake out excess water or spin the brush in a brush spinner.  
   • Gently reshape the bristles with your fingers.  
   • Lay the brush flat or hang it by the handle hole so water can’t seep into the ferrule.  
   • Once dry, slip it back into the original sleeve or wrap it in heavy paper to maintain its form.

Safety & disposal
• Work in a well-ventilated area, away from ignition sources—solvents are flammable.  
• Wear chemical-resistant gloves and eye protection.  
• Let used solvent sit in a sealed jar; paint solids will settle to the bottom overnight. Strain the clear solvent back into a clean container for reuse and take the sludge to a hazardous-waste facility or a paint-recycling drop-off. Never pour it down a drain.

Tip for short breaks
If you’ll resume painting within a day or two, skip full cleaning: suspend the brush in a small container of clean mineral spirits with the bristles fully immersed, or tightly wrap the bristles in plastic wrap and refrigerate. Clean thoroughly when you’re finished with the project.

Follow these steps and your oil-based brushes will stay soft, maintain their shape, and deliver a smooth finish for years to come.

How do I touch up small areas of painted walls?

Touching up painted walls is one of those projects that can be quick and invisible—or surprisingly noticeable—depending on how you approach it. The key is in good preparation, the right tools and paint, and careful blending. Below is a step-by-step guide to get those small nicks, scuffs, nail holes, or scratches looking flawless again.

––––––––––––––
1. Gather Your Supplies
––––––––––––––
• Matching paint (ideally from the same can used originally; if not, ask Zava’s paint desk to color-match a sample or the paint code).  
• Small paintbrush or high-density foam brush.  
• 4-inch mini foam roller (for larger touch-ups or low-texture walls).  
• Fine-grit sandpaper (220- to 320-grit) or a sanding sponge.  
• Spackling compound (for holes or deeper dents).  
• Putty knife or a flexible taping knife.  
• Clean, lint-free cloth and mild detergent solution.  
• Painter’s tape (optional, mostly for trim or tight corners).  
• Small paint tray or disposable plate.  
• Primer (stain-blocking or bonding, only if bare drywall or patched areas show).

––––––––––––––
2. Prepare the Surface
––––––––––––––
1. Clean: Lightly wipe the area with a damp, soapy cloth to remove dust, oil or fingerprints. Let it dry completely.  
2. Repair:  
   • For pinholes or shallow nicks: dab a bit of spackle with your fingertip, scrape flush with the putty knife.  
   • For nail or screw holes: overfill slightly with spackle, let it dry, then sand smooth.  
3. Sand: Feather the edges using fine-grit sandpaper so the patched spot is level with the surrounding paint film. Wipe away dust with a dry cloth.

––––––––––––––
3. Prime if Necessary
––––––––––––––
• If you exposed bare drywall, joint compound, or a dark mark that might bleed through, apply a tiny amount of primer just on the repair.  
• Allow it to dry fully (usually 30–60 minutes for quick-dry primers).

––––––––––––––
4. Mix and Test Your Paint
––––––––––––––
• Stir the paint thoroughly; separated pigments can create a mismatched sheen.  
• Do a small test swipe on scrap cardboard or a concealed wall area to be sure the color looks right once it dries. Remember that the final sheen appears after 1–2 hours.

––––––––––––––
5. Apply the Touch-Up
––––––––––––––
For very small spots (pinhead- to dime-sized):
• Use an artist’s brush or narrow craft brush. Lightly dab (do not brush in long strokes) to stipple paint only on the blemish. Try to stay inside the original area.

For patches up to roughly a credit-card size:
• A 1- to 2-inch angle sash brush works well. Feather the edges: place the brush in the center, then gently sweep outward so paint thins toward the edges. This helps blend with the surrounding film.

For larger areas (softball-size or bigger):
• A 4-inch high-density foam mini roller typically gives the closest match to the original roller texture. Load the roller lightly, roll off excess on a tray, then roll over the patch and 2–3 inches beyond in a “W” or criss-cross pattern.

Pro tip: If the wall has an orange-peel or knockdown texture, you can mimic it by tapping a slightly loaded sponge or roller before the paint dries.

––––––––––––––
6. Watch Your Sheen and Lighting
––––––––––––––
• The glossier the paint (satin, semi-gloss), the more obvious a touch-up can be. Keep application thin and even.  
• Evaluate under the same lighting that normally hits the wall. A spot that looks perfect under warm evening light may flash (look different) in midday sun.

––––––––––––––
7. Let It Dry and Blend
––––––––––––––
• Resist the urge to keep touching it! Paint usually darkens as it dries; initial contrast often fades.  
• After 2–4 hours (or the time listed on your paint can), check the result. If it still shows, a second light coat—slightly larger than the first—will often disappear.

––––––––––––––
8. When a Small Touch-Up Isn’t Enough
––––––––––––––
If the touched-up area remains obvious, consider:
• Repainting the entire wall section from corner to corner; seams in corners or at trim naturally hide start/stop marks.  
• Using a paint additive like Floetrol (for latex) to extend open time and improve blending.

––––––––––––––
Quick Reference Tips
––––––––––––––
• Keep leftover paint sealed and labeled to ensure an exact match in the future.  
• Temperature matters: 10-30 °C (50-85 °F) and low humidity give the most consistent drying.  
• For apartment renters, many standard whites are premixed; bring a small paint chip (even from behind a switch plate) to Zava so we can match it.  
• Store brushes in a zip bag between coats to keep them from drying out.

With these steps and a little patience, you should end up with a seamless finish that looks like the mark never existed. If you need specific primer recommendations, color-matching help, or advice on textured walls, feel free to stop by or call your local Zava—our paint experts are happy to help.
